articles.headline: Is Norway the Future of Cars?
articles.snippet: The speed by which electric vehicles have taken over Norway has stunned even the cars’ enthusiasts.
articles.abstract: The speed by which electric vehicles have taken over Norway has stunned even the cars’ enthusiasts.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.

articles.headline: Why Coronavirus Testing Is Falling Short in Many Schools Across the U.S.
articles.snippet: As millions of American students head back to their desks, the virus testing that was supposed to help keep classrooms open safely is itself being tested.
articles.abstract: As millions of American students head back to their desks, the virus testing that was supposed to help keep classrooms open safely is itself being tested.
articles.lead_paragraph: In California, storms over the winter break destroyed a million coronavirus test kits that were meant to help schools screen returning students. In Seattle schools, children waited for hours for virus testing, some in a driving rain. In Florida this month, an attempt to supply tests to teachers in Broward County turned up expired kits.

articles.headline: A Facebook antitrust suit can move forward, a judge says, in a win for the F.T.C.
articles.snippet: The government can proceed with its claims that the company abused its monopoly power through acquisitions.
articles.abstract: The government can proceed with its claims that the company abused its monopoly power through acquisitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Tuesday allowed the Federal Trade Commission’s antitrust lawsuit against Facebook to move forward, rejecting Facebook’s request to dismiss the case and handing the agency a major victory in its quest to curtail the power of the biggest tech companies.

articles.headline: Putin’s Next Move on Ukraine Is a Mystery. Just the Way He Likes It.
articles.snippet: The contradictory, sometimes menacing messages from the Kremlin have stumped Western officials and Russia experts, showing the Russian leader’s desire to keep his rivals on edge.
articles.abstract: The contradictory, sometimes menacing messages from the Kremlin have stumped Western officials and Russia experts, showing the Russian leader’s desire to keep his rivals on edge.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENEVA — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has spent months massing close to 100,000 troops near the Ukraine border. But Moscow says it has no intention of invading.

articles.headline: A Voting Rights Push, as States Make Voting Harder
articles.snippet: President Biden says he won’t keep “quiet” any longer about protecting ballot access. But voting rights groups say he should’ve raised his voice months ago.
articles.abstract: President Biden says he won’t keep “quiet” any longer about protecting ballot access. But voting rights groups say he should’ve raised his voice months ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the nine months since Republicans in Georgia muscled through a host of new voting restrictions, 18 other states have enacted 33 such laws. More than 30 states have concluded their redistricting processes, with extreme partisan gerrymandering locking in Republican control over legislatures in the electoral battlegrounds of Georgia, North Carolina, Ohio and Texas for another 10 years.
articles.byline: By Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein

articles.headline: Why Some Workers Are Getting All the Covid Tests They Need
articles.snippet: In the absence of a national effort to make coronavirus testing widely available, a number of big American companies ramped up their own, making tests available for a select group of workers.
articles.abstract: In the absence of a national effort to make coronavirus testing widely available, a number of big American companies ramped up their own, making tests available for a select group of workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The latest Covid-19 wave has left millions of Americans scrambling for tests, braving long lines in the cold at pop-up sites or searching furiously online for kits to use at home. But for a select group of employees at some of the country’s largest companies, tests are free and often readily available.
articles.byline: By Emma Goldberg, Lauren Hirsch and David McCabe

articles.headline: The Army of Millions Who Enforce China’s Zero-Covid Policy, at All Costs
articles.snippet: As the troubled lockdown in Xi’an has shown, many Chinese people remain willing to work diligently toward the government’s goal of eliminating the virus, no matter the consequences.
articles.abstract: As the troubled lockdown in Xi’an has shown, many Chinese people remain willing to work diligently toward the government’s goal of eliminating the virus, no matter the consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: China’s “zero Covid” policy has a dedicated following: the millions of people who work diligently toward that goal, no matter the human costs.

articles.headline: Consumer prices popped again in December, casting a shadow over the economy.
articles.snippet: The Consumer Price Index increased at the fastest pace in 40 years, a new report showed.
articles.abstract: The Consumer Price Index increased at the fastest pace in 40 years, a new report showed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inflation climbed to its highest level in 40 years at the end of 2021, a troubling development for President Biden and economic policymakers as rapid price gains erode consumer confidence and cast a shadow of uncertainty over the economy’s future.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: After a ‘horrendous’ 2021, the I.R.S. will start the tax season with a major backlog.
articles.snippet: At least 10 million returns from last year remain unprocessed because of short-staffing at the tax collector, according to the national taxpayer advocate.
articles.abstract: At least 10 million returns from last year remain unprocessed because of short-staffing at the tax collector, according to the national taxpayer advocate.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Internal Revenue Service will kick off the approaching tax season with a backlog of at least 10 million unprocessed returns from last year, according to a new report by the national taxpayer advocate.
